discussion.content:
Definitely D, but not so sure about C. 
I'm leaning more towards B and D.

EXAM TIP    Account management security policy best practices dictate that you should implement restrictive user permissions, login time restrictions, account lockout based on failed attempts, and disable the operating system’s built-in AutoRun or AutoPlay features. Finally, you should always change default system user names and passwords where possible.
-Mike Meyers ebook

CE are the right answer, Autorun is a microsoft function and deactivating itwould not prevent boot from a device. Secure boot preventivo from booting from external drive and set a strong password would prevent anyone to make any change in the uefi / bios.

Selected Answer: CE
Autorun is a microsoft function and deactivating itwould not prevent boot from a device.

Secure boot preventivo from booting from external drive and set a strong password would prevent anyone to make any change in the uefi / bios.
What I don't like of C us that doesn't specify if is user or administrator

I checked on atleast 4 different websites and they show A and B as the right answer which clearly don't make sense at all.

D is surely an answer here

Selected Answer: DF
"an unauthorized user(f. using default admin creds to launch non-native OS) was able to insert a USB flash drive into a kiosk(d. disable usb autorun), launch a non-native OS, and deliver malicious payloads"
Default credentials and autorun

I think C is correct, in order to not allow anyone to change the boot order to boot from USB. So C D sounds about right. Secure boot keeps rootkits from attaching to the OS and unsigned drivers out, not helpful so much in this case I think.
D, E maybe? wouldn't secure boot prevent the OS from running?

comments.content: yup, D & E are correct. Anyone could just to boot startup via USB. Enabling Secure Boot will definitely disable boot to USB. Back in my previous job, we always disable Secure Boot in order to boot via USB.

questions.question_text:
A company recently experienced a security incident in which an unauthorized user was able to insert a USB flash drive into a kiosk, launch a non-native OS, and deliver malicious payloads across the network.
Which of the following security measures would have been BEST to prevent the attack from being executed in the first place? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Implementing automatic screen locks after 60 seconds of inactivity
choices.A: Using a host-based antivirus with real-time scanning

questions.question_text:
A technician has created a new fileshare for an organization. To maintain data security, all users should have read-only rights to the fileshare. Additionally, supervisors need to be able to write and delete files. After the technician has configured the fileshare, users can read documents, but supervisors cannot modify documents.
Which of the following utilities should the technician use to troubleshoot the issue?

discussion.content: I also believe the answer B is correct per Mike Meyers book. If you google UAC and changing NTFS permissions it also shows up
What about Group Policy? Since there are multiple clients (supervisors).

comments.content: I think it is the closest answer

If it was available yeah that would make the most sense. In this case though, it should be B. UAC as the best answer. Local Security Policy cannot interfere with NTFS permissions as far as I'm aware. 
From Meyers
"Security Policies
Security policies are rules applied to users and groups to do, well, just about everything but NTFS permissions. Would you like to configure your system so that the Accounting group can only log on between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M.? There’s a security policy for that. How about forcing anyone who logs on to your system to use a password that’s at least eight characters long? There’s a security policy for that as well. Windows provides thousands of preset security policies that you may use simply by turning them on in a utility called Local Security Policy."

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Disk encryption is designed to encrypt the entire contents of a disk, making the data on the disk unreadable without the appropriate decryption key. This helps protect the data on the workstation's hard drive-in case the workstation is stolen. It provides a comprehensive layer of security for the entire disk and the data stored on it.

Selected Answer: D
Its D. Data in transit encryption seems more like for the credit card device (separate from the workstation) and the other 2 dont protect a workstation from theft.

Selected Answer: D
I go for D

"in case of theft"
"In case of theft" makes me think disk encryption might be best for the workstation.

comments.content: Agreed, D makes the most sense to secure the terminal in case it gets stolen.

questions.question_text:
A technician has been tasked with installing a workstation that will be used for point-of-sale transactions. The point-of-sale system will process credit cards and loyalty cards.
Which of the following encryption technologies should be used to secure the workstation in case of theft?

choices.D: There is no malware on the workstation
choices.A: The technician should not have disabled System Restore
choices.B: The technician never quarantined the workstation
choices.C: The technician did not update the anti-malware software

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer is correct. The malware scanner could be out dated and potentially didn't have the correct signatures so you'd need to update it before running a scan.
I would have chose D for this but I could be wrong.

questions.question_text:
A user's workstation is running extremely slow. A technician sees a pop-up on the workstation offering what appears to be fake technical support, so the technician begins the malware removal procedure. After disabling System Restore, the technician runs a malware scan, but the scan does not find any malware on the machine.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason the technician cannot find any malware?

A project team is organized to implement a new wireless solution for a school. The team has already done the network diagrams and knows the locations that will need to be addressed in the project. The team is in the process of creating an SOW for the project as a whole and needs to add the critical pieces to the SOW to complete it and move to the next stage.
Which of the following would the project team MOST likely add to the SOW?

discussion.content: just in case - SOW means statement of work.

OK, I guess it's back out plan because "The team has already done the network diagrams and knows the locations that will need to be addressed in the project." so it's implied they have already made a plan and the risk analysis should come before the plan. the change board approval is not vital to add so back up plan it is. Otherwise I don't know how to make sense of it.

Selected Answer: A
The project team would most likely add a risk analysis to the SOW. This is because a risk analysis helps identify potential risks or challenges that may arise during the project and allows the team to develop a plan to mitigate them. It is important to include a risk analysis in the SOW to ensure that the project team is aware of the risks involved and has a plan to address them.

Plan to change, backout plan, and change board approvals may also be important components of the SOW, but they are not as critical as a risk analysis, which helps ensure the success of the project. While a backout plan is important, it is usually included as part of the implementation plan rather than the SOW.

Documented business processes
• Purpose of the change
• Scope the change
• Risk analysis
• Plan for change
• End-user acceptance
• Change board
- Approvals
• Backout plan
• Document changes
This is the order....so why the answer is not change board approvals?

Selected Answer: C
The irony here is that the official comptia texts don't actually define the Statement of Work directly. but the section regarding change management documentation lists all four of the provided choices as items that should be on it. So what does CompTIA want us to answer here? The CompTIA text lists the "backout plan" last, but it is in BOLD lettering, so that has to be the answer. Be smarter than the test.

Searched up what is listed in a SOW.

Purpose of the project
Scope of work being performed
Location of the project, project length, and any work requirements
Expected deadlines and deliverables
Acceptance criteria
Any hardware and software required
Performance-based standards to be met

Benefits can include:
Increased cost savings opportunities
Supplier performance and risk mitigation
Greater process efficiencies
Detailed reporting 
Project performance management
Visibility into all outsourced projects within a single purview
Improved workforce management
Organisational compliance and risk mitigation

https://www.guidantglobal.com/what-is-outsourcing/what-is-statement-of-work-sow#:~:text=A%20statement%20of%20work%20(SOW,and%20payment%20terms%20and%20conditions.
The answer is Backout Plan because a SOW (Statement of Work) is done once majority of the other change management steps have been implemented. It's done towards the end.
Risk Analysis should be the next step after determining the scope
A backout plan is an IT governance integration approach that specifies the processes required to restore a system to its original or earlier state, in the event of failed or aborted implementation.

As safety comes always first i believe that making a Risk Analysis is a must. It is a bigger problem if a WAP gets installed close to a vibrating HVAC duct where it could fall on somebody's head than roll back the change incase someone's phone does not support the 5GHz range.
Back out plan is the most important answer here, IT IS A MUST, in order to move to the next stage. Because if you have a backout plan, you'll probably have the rest done as well.

Documented business processes
• Purpose of the change
• Scope the change
• Risk analysis
• Plan for change
• End-user acceptance
• Change board
- Approvals
• Backout plan
• Document changes
Why not go risk analysis first? Backup plan should be the last step, right?
@ Ziberteck, SOW concept falls more under Project Management lingo.
Does anyone know what section this falls under? I never read anything about SOW's in the book I was reading. And it doesn't seem to be listed in the exam topics.

Without the backout plan, if something goes wrong during the change, you have no plan to roll it back to its previous state. At that point, either you take a lot of unaccounted for time to figure out the backout steps (also make the company/client rather angry for not being prepared as well as wasting valuable time) or have to cough up the losses that the company incurred while the system is down...or maybe even both depending on the terms agreed upon for the project. If its an internal job, this could result in termination. Either way, it will definitely be a resume generating event that will haunt your career for a long time.
The Testout program uses purpose of change, plan of change, scope of change, risk analysis, and a backout plan. Wouldnt these all be correct answers? Or why would the backout plan be most needed?
